reviewText: By now, fans of each band know how successful their two-season tour has been.  Since it's unlikely that CHI and EW&F; will hit the road together in 2006, this DVD is a great item to own.The performance captured here is terrific.  Both bands perform with energy and style (unlike some of the subsequent 2005 shows, where lighting, sound, and a shortened set list plagued Chicago).  As others have noted, the highlights happen when the bands perform together; particularly great is the brass performance on Chicago's "Free"--a tour deforce for EW&F; saxman Gary Bias and the rest of the horns.  Also really cool are Phillip Bailey's soaring high notes, Bill Champlin's rendition of "After the Love Is Gone," Russian guitarist Vadim Zibershtein's solo on "25 or 6 to 4," and the combined joy evident in this rendition of "September Song."Individual sets rock, too.  EW&F; simple defy age and gravity, and the relatively new horn section (Reggie Young, Bias, and Bob Burns) rips.  The Chicago set captured here is almost as high-energy, and the famous Chicago horns (Jimmy Pankow, Lee Loughnane, Walt Parazaider) play tweaked arrangements perfectly and with style.  My only compaint is that I feel Chicago does too many of their ballad hits to 'compete' with EW&F;, but I'm sure I'm in the minority; most fans would probably select exactly the same songs the band performs here.In short, it's great to see those two powerhouse bands at the top of their game, pushing each other and obviously enjoying it.  As Robert Lamm says, "Music is unity."  This is a DVD well worth owning.

reviewText: The vast number of excellent reviews of this concert sufficiently puts the nit-picky criticisms to bed, so I'll only briefly address critics by saying that any reviewer who would comment that the sound engineering was poor enough to make the concert as exciting as a "PBS pledge drive" either watched this concert with the power off or with a sack over his head, or both. The disk's engineers tackle well the difficult job of toggling back and forth between one large band and then two playing simultaneously. The resulting DVD sounds very good and is filmed well, despite some overly zippy editing and (inexcusable) failure to detail most of the guitar finger work. It's true that there's been a weakening of vocals in both bands, but that's inevitable given the passage of time and easily overlooked when one considers the electricity these performers still discharge on stage. I saw the bands together at Merriweather Post Pavilion in Maryland and can attest that they give 110% pure energy. Special shouts go out to EWF trombonist Reggie Young whose feet are in permanent motion throughout the concert and whose personality clearly and happily infects the whole theater. EWF's David Whitworth sounds great and keeps the energy level high. Watch for inspired solos by EWF guitarist Vadim Zilberstein. Chicago's Keith Howland must be one of the great underestimated guitarists in the business. Effortless is not a strong enough word to describe the way he plays lightning-fast, crisp Hendrix-Kath-inspired guitar. It's a pleasure to watch the joyous interaction between drummers Tris Imboden and John Paris; the expressions on their faces say more about this concert than all the words on this webpage. During the two-band finale, the whole stage shakes, which is interestingly captured in some of the camera work. One reviewer says of the finale that he dances on the walls every time he watches; that ought to be a sight. I'll simply say that they close with a blazing three-guitar fest--Howland, Zilberstein, and Greg Moore--on "25 or 6 to 4" that absolutely blows your doors off. Review no. 179. Hope it is helpful.

reviewText: If you're a fan of Chicago and Earth, Wind, and Fire then you will definitely want to add this DVD to your musical collection.  A 2-DVD set that tops out at 172 minutes, "Live At the Greek Theater" has a fantastic 5.1 Dolby sound that is crisp and pure and showcases the talent of these great musicians.  The cinematography, set designs and lighting are all top-notch and help to make this experience a treat for the senses.I've been a Chicago fan for years, but had little contact with EWF, so I was blown away by their energy and sheer musical abilities.  Lead singer Philip Bailey has amazing range and has the charisma to carry the EWF set.  The EWF DVD contains many of their memorable hits that sound as good today as they did in the 70's and 80's.  This band has not aged.  They blend so well with Chicago in the opening and closing acts that it's hard to believe they haven't been performing together for years.The Chicago set contains lengthy versions of many of their greatest hits, mixed successfully between 70's and 80's staples.They start with what is described as the "Make Me Smile Medley" which contains many of the selections from the "Ballet for a Girl From Buchannon" suite in "Chicago II" and end with "Hard To Say I'm Sorry/Get Away".  In between are nothing but classics.  Robert Lamm sounds great and the power trio of Walt Parazaider, Jimmy Pankow, and Lee Loughnane (the four remaining original members of the band) are in great form.This DVD is not to be missed!
summary: Two great bands packaged in a great DVD!

reviewText: As  they tell us, these guys (plus one woman) have been around for more than 30 years....at least, the core of each band has. It shows in a most positive way. While the bands may be particularly up or down on any given night, the concert tour organizers and the audiences know that most nights a group of solid professionals, highly skilled on their instruments, well rehearsed in the basic format of their program, will turn in a performance that will make the average audience happy. So it seems was true the evening this DVD was "cut". The sequence is described in Amazon's comments: an introduction by  both bands, a separate set for each, and then a prolonged finale by both. While each is a rock band set in their style for decades, they are enogh different in instrumental, physical and, particularly, vocal styles, to make a long program sufficiently diverse to maintain interest. Earth, Wind and Fire is a set of vocalists  supported by a fine  band, Chicago is a fine band with good vocalists.The first offers a more outgoing, audience-interactive demeanor, the latter a more focused instrumental ensemble. Their finale together is a typical all-out razzmatazz set, which, as used to be said, deservedly has the joint jumping. As is its intention, it overrides any  quibbles most in the audience will have had with particulars in the previous performances. As with the live audience, so with the DVD audience, you should end the session well satisfied with the concert. Oh, yes, as is almost always the case with these live endeavors, if you know the songs sung, you will be ahead of the game, as most lyrics are not sung to  be comprehended.
summary: JUST FOR OTHERS WHO NEVER HEARD EITHER BAND BEFORE

reviewText: First, I have to say that even though there are some songs from both groups that I like, but never enough to buy their albums. But concerts are just different, some of my favorite artists, their concerts were just a waste, from poor sound/lighting/video/etc. Now that said, after reading the reviews on this dvd, I decided to see what $18.00 would get me.I was just so impressed, the two groups together, how they shared songs and just made the stage come alive- I am watching this on my 220" panasonic system with Klips reference speakers all around. Even at this size, the picture did not disappoint. From the opening number, you are just absorbed into the energy- and yes- they were having fun as they should. It brought a strong feeling that will keep you coming back to watch over and over again. It reminds me of Hall & Oats live at the troubadour (blue ray), and Sting- Live in Berlin (blue ray).  Picture quality from these two are,,, well, I can count the threads on the microphones screws, the scratches on each guitar, to the veins in their throats. Sound,  I have not capped it out but the mix is fantastic, and if you have the sub, you will be moving furniture!The other 5 star reviews are just dead on and I appreciate their feedback giving me the initiative to purchase this concert. Welcome to my system Chicago/EWF!

reviewText: This concert features two of the best acts in music for many, many years.The concert was really in four pieces, both bands opening together, EWF primarily alone, then Chicago primarily alone,  then a strong finish together.I personally thought the best parts of the concert are when they perform together.  I never could have imagined these two bands blending, but they did.  They seemed to really enjoy each others music, and performing each others songs.Chicago's instumentals were totally wonderful.  I thought the vocals were pretty weak though, and was the weak link of the performances. Their voices thin and showing their age.  In spite of this, I still enjoyed it.EWF performed very well both vocally and instumentally.  Together as stated, it was awesome.Video and audio were very good, and they sure projected an image of two bands having a great time.For two bands generally in their 50's and 60's, they played a very long crowd pleasing set.  I highly recommend you own this concert.Jerry
summary: BRINGS BACK A LOT OF MEMORIES
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I saw this DVD with both bands at the same concert, I saw it as a must have.The good points first - good introduction with both bands performimg 3-4 numbers. Earth Wind & Fire sound as good as they ever have on any CD I have heard. Time has not changed their sound, just brilliant.The DVD sound and picture quality are very good, as you would expect from recent recordings.Now for the disappointing stuff. I was really looking forward to hearing EWF's song, "After The Love Has Gone". The lead singer from Chicago actually wrote it and HE comes on to do the lead vocals. EWF's vocal backing are brilliant but the song is ruined by the Chicago singer - his voice has deteriorated over the years and struggles to get the notes out - you would not recognise him if you have not heard the band since the 1970's or 1980's.Chicago's best easy listening song "If You Leave Me Now" is sung by the EWF lead singer - although he can still sing and does a nice job, it does not sound like the song you wanted to hear Chicago sing.Chicago these day, have several young singers in the band and with the aging lead singer struggling a bit, none of the vocals sound anything like the 70's an 80's recordings you are used to hearing.The concert is still well produced and put together, but I wish I had bought a DVD with just EWF on it.
summary: Not As Good As It Looks !!

reviewText: Take two legendary groups from the '70's and '80's, put them in one of the greatest venues in the USA, and prepare yourself for one unforgettable show! Both groups perform all their best hits, and even join forces for many of them. The sound is amazing on most of it, but there was one problem, which I'll cover below. Notably absent from this concert was Peter Cetera, whose voice was omnipresent on so many of Chicago's songs. Keith Howland performed most of the songs Cetera sang on the albums, and did so quite well. But I still would have preferred to have the original voice there. Howland was one of the younger band members (definitely not one of the originals), but was as adept with Chicago's songs as any of the founding members, all of whom must be in their 60's by now. Robert Lamm looked and sounded great; there must be a picture of him somewhere doing the Dorian Gray bit. I mentioned a problem with the sound; apparently, on the second disc, the DTS track is missing the rear channels. Being an audiophile, I prefer DTS over Dolby Digital when the choice is available. But the Dolby Digital track on disc 2 is complete with rear channels. I have to wonder if Image Entertainment is aware of this problem. It's due to this that I give this set only 4 stars rather than 5. I'm not aware of any albums available in surround from Earth, Wind, and Fire, but Chicago II and V are available on DVD-Audio with full 5.1 sound.Both are worth adding to your collection.

reviewText: OK. I haven't seen the DVD.BUT I just saw Chicago and EWF in concert, doing the same show. All I can say is that if the CD has half the energy and technical perfection of the show, this is one heckuva of a product!Chicago and EWF are at that awkward age. With half their members still alive and blowing, they are somewhere halfway between a tribute band and the finest incarnation of their young selves. On stage, the members of each band seem to be having the time of their lives. And why not? 30 years after their heyday, they are still popular, still bringing their fans in by the thousands. The audience shouts their lyrics back at them, hums along with their well-worn brass breaks and cheers for every opening riff. Both bands are down to half their original strength, but the cross-pollination has done wonders for both. The bands play together and apart, feeding off each other and the audience, helping us all forget our troubles for a few sweet hours.Don't make any mistake: I missed some of their founding members. Terry Kath, Peter Cetera, Danny Seraphine and Maurice White have either gone to the big gig in the sky or moved on to other projects and careers. But both bands have managed to keep fresh songs that have been overplayed by FM radio almost to the point of cliché, making these old chestnuts fun, with new arrangements and plain old fashioned energy.A sure bet to make you smile ;-)
summary: Gotta be as fun as the concert

reviewText: If you did not see this incredible tour last year here is your chance. Almost 3 fantastic hours from two of the greatest rock & R n B bands of all time. The beginning and ending where both bands are onstage is worth the purchase price alone! If you are a fan of either band or a fan of 70's music in general this is one not to miss! If this great show comes to your town this year you should go see it live as well. The early reviews are that it is great as well.Time for an edit in of gripes with some reviewers.1- Jay L. Rudko - Hey Jay my boy Peter Cetera has been a solo act now for 20 years. If you expected him the show up for this show, you must really be Rip Van Winkle. And Jason Scheff does the majority of Peter's songs. Keith only does one or two depending on the set list.2- Nathan - Hey Nate that "Medley" you refer to is the "Ballet for a Girl in Buchannon" written by Jimmy Pankow See Chicago II for the original studio version. And Hard to Say I'm Sorry/Get Away is presented as it was on Chi 16 (with a repeat helping of Get Away and some horns added on HTSIS) And what "Lesser known songs" are you referring to? Also PC left of his own accord and Champlin was brought into the band cause it was thought that Robert Lamm might leave the band at some point. And how can you say Jason and Bill's singing is inadequate, versus who???? PC's voice isn't all it used to be either.3 & 4 - Emacomber & Bluzman - You two make zero sense at all, and that is more than enough to be said about the two of you except to say that I am sure that Maurice would love to be healthy enough to still be touring with EWF. Sadly he has Parkinsons Disease and can not tour. But I do understand that he will be on EWF's new studio CD due out this summer!
summary: Chicago/EWF the hottest tour of 2004 and here's why!!!

reviewText: After much delay, this disc is finally released  so; what do we have.  Overall the concert is a great experience.  I thought the direction was outstanding, with some great shot choices and timing.  It is my understanding that the video was captured in 2004, which may explain why the occasional shot doesn't hold up to blu-ray full potential as to clarity.  Am going to assume that most buying this disc are fans of the bands, so you already know that both now contain a substantial percentage of non-original members.One of the most fascinating aspects of the show to me is how well the bands mesh during their two sets together (both the opening and closing of the show).  It's a real treat and am sure you will like it.  It is during the separation that the differences become more stark.  EWF goes first, and the fact that most are hired guns aside, there is no question that EWF showcases superior musicianship.  The groves are intense, and the energy is omnipresent.  About the only oddity in the group is that Philip Bailey has placed his wife in the band, who in my opinion added nothing to an otherwise stellar lineup.Bailey's voice truly delivers, including a beautiful showcase vocal solo.  The harmonies are there.  As to the musicianship, I assure you there are chops aplenty, but they never once clutter the grove.  It's just beautiful.Then, Chicago take the stage, choosing to open with some fairly bland obscure material, which is especially stark given the immediate contrast to the remarkably powerful set they are following.  They do warm up as the set progresses, but in my opinion never equal the EWF show, though it's be no means a bad overall performance.  To their credit the percentage of original members is much higher.While members from both bands "guest" during the other's solo set, I was hoping that each band would choose a tune from the other and do their own arrangement of it, but alas this was not to be.I want to specifically discuss the mix, as in my experience that is something often overlooked in disc reviews, and it seems to me valid info for anyone investing in gear taking advantage of blu-ray capability.  I used the DTS HD Master Audio 5.1 mix for this review, played in a well equipped and balanced theatre setup.  The mix uses the rear speakers sparingly; I think a bit more of the crowd response would have been fun.  Once in awhile one of the instruments will show up there too.  The mix when the two bands are onstage together is wonderful, as is the mix of EWF.  However, Chicago's set, for no apparent reason, was rendered thin.  There is no reason why a band with two keyboardists shouldn't sound fuller, and at times the harmonies and the occasional string line seemed too far back in the mix.  Also, the toms were continually mixed far lower and out of balance than the rest of the drumkit, so quite a few of the drum riffs intended to add power were rendered weak.  On a positive note, I found the recording of the cymbals of both kits to be some of the most pristine capture I've heard on any disc.Forget extra materials; there aren't any, save for a drum and percussion dual which might have been better served left in the concert itself rather than isolated.Overall you will really like this disc, from both a visual and audio standpoint.  Can't go with five stars for the reasons listed, but it's a solid four star, and well worth a listen.
summary: Very solid disc, though not ideal

reviewText: back in the day I was a Huge Earth,wind&Fire Fan.the past will always rank real high for me,but it's been hard to see what they have Morphed into. in fact the same can be said about Chicago. because once both acts had David Foster's Smoothed out Synths&Shine added to there work they were never the same acts again.tougher for me with Earth,Wind&Fire because there Band as it was  would wreck a house the Rock&Roll Hall of Fame Performance showcased that.this Version of Earth,Wind&Fire is like a Local Band at my area Holiday Inn that has the songs,etc... down pat,but lacks any real soul&Vibe. seems like they have done the same thing 30 times before in a 31 day month. that is the Problem I have with Modern day live EWF.I ain't even gonna comment on the Studio stuff,because it is Flat&beneath there Legacy. as for chicago:they sound good on the Horns,etc... I would have dug having these two acts together back about 10-15 years ago. there is alot of energy&Talent here,but having followed both Acts it feels like a American Express Performance as to two Acts that are still showcasing themselves at there best. it's pretty Good but a bit too Polished for my tastes.
summary: Pretty Good, a bit too much Vegas Polish for me

reviewText: Chicago has definitely lost some steam.  The original guys have lost their chops, and the younger fill-in guys are anonymous pretty-boys who try to sound like Cetera, Kath, et al.  They were truly great in the '70's, but it's time to hang it up.  EWF still has some fire left, thanks to a GREAT rhythm section, decent horns, and Phillip Bailey.  The guitar player looks like Larry Flynt.  Verdine the bass player needs to drink some more coffee (I say this tongue-in-cheek).  I think he enjoyed this show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This show is marvelous. I've been a Chicago fan since their first album in the late 60's. Chicago's Color My World was our Prom theme (Color our World) and at our wedding we had a group much like chicago, needless to say I am a Chicago fan. I saw Earth Wind and Fire live in concert at the Ontario Speedway in 1974 at the California Jam. These are "True Musicians" Both bands ROCK and I mean Rock! See the show you will not be sorry.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The quality of this DVD in Bluray is very good - both visually and in sound quality.  Not Stunning, but very good.  Bluray is an excellent medium, but only as good as the original recording.  Staging and lighting in the concert were below par by today's standards, but the fun on the stage and the sheer number of musicians counteracts the lack of dazzling lighting.Chicago was excellent (their wind players especially had a lot of energy and played with inspiration), but EWF had the most mojo here.  Chicago was best and most youthful when playing with EWF.This is a fun get together concert.  If you're a hard core EWF and/or Chicago fan, it's worth buying, otherwise, rent it.

reviewText: Great audio and video accuracy. High energy by both bands. All of the greatest hits covered by both. Well worth the price - captures the essence of 2 big bands from the 80's. Youll crank this up as loud as your neighbors will allow!

Title: N/A

reviewText: This Blu-ray disc is worth every penny of an already incredible price.The performance and blend of the two bands was excellent.I must say that the song I wanted to listen although it was listed as included within the EWF list of songs ("The Way You Move") was not actually performed, but just as low volume background while doing the band introductions.If I would have a suggestion for the camera crew was that while the idea of fixing the cameras on the stage floor might have been clever considering how busy that stage was, it was not a good one at times due to the vibrations that were transmitted to the shots, especially noticeable on objects behind the close ups.  However, the mixing was made in a way that reduced that effect due to the short shots.Overall, the experience was excellent.

reviewText: If you like a driving Heavy Jazz Rock sound with a lot of Brass this will not disappoint.  I really enjoyed the "concert" over all but really miss Peter Cetera, the original bass player, and Terry Kath the original guitarist.  Chicago doesn't seem quite like Chicago with out those 2.  Even though Earth Wind & Fire are missing many of there original members, they have done a better overall job at keeping there sound and emotion the same over the years.

reviewText: Don't buy this for the Chicago set.  Its ok, but lacks the brilliant Peter Cetera vocals.  Earth, Wind, and Fire is the reason to buy and listen to this.  The music and vocals are great and sound the same as they did 30 years ago.  Way of the World is beautiful and they play all the favorites.  One of the best music DVD's I own strictly for EW&F.

reviewText: Couldn't agree better than with the previous feedback.  This is an awesome concert with lots of EWF and Chicago's catchy tunes.  What a synergy between the two bands!  Video is presented in 1080i/60, which is totally acceptable for concerts.  It's brilliantly filmed.  Audio is either 5.1 DTS HD MA, 5.1 Dolby Digital, or PCM 2.0.  Both 5.1 surround sounds are great, but no doubt the DTS HD MA sound is superior to the Dolby Digital one.  As far as concerts on Blu-Ray are concerned, only Shakira would top this one in my opinion.  Better get both!
summary: Awesome concert in 1080i/60 and 5.1 DTS HD MA / 5.1 Dolby Digital / PCM 2.0
Title: N/A

reviewText: There's not too much I can add to the stellar reviews of this DVD.  All I can say is that you can play this for any kid and they'll be begging you to let them join the band.  A great party DVD especially if there are musicians around although anyone will enjoy it.  Outstanding sound from two of my all-time favorite groups!Also, check out both lead singers recent solo albums: "Soul on Jazz" by Philip Bailey and "Subtlety & Passion" by Robert Lamm.  Bailey creates a mellow CD and  Lamm's CD is especially superb featuring most of the members of Chicago with horns on ALL the cuts, great writing and Lamm's magical voice.  A better-than-Chicago delight!

reviewText: I DVR'd this concert (in hi-def and 5.1) off of INHD and have watched many times.  The concerts they have shown have been identical to the DVD's of the same name so I'm assuming the same will hold true on this release.  (DVD has a few MORE songs than concert shown on cable- see below)  This show is about two hours long with the combined bands starting together for a few songs, then EWF, then Chicago, and then combined again for the last three or so.  I bought concert tickets for later this summer after seeing this.  The sound quality is superb which now I understand as it was produced by Image who did the first Eagles and Steely Dan DVD's, and always have superior production.  The DVD also has a DTS track.  As far as the performance, I think 1+1 >2.  I have the Chicago Soundstage DVD and the EWF Live by Request and this is better than both.  Chicago particularly benefits as their energy level is much higher here than on the solo disc.  EWF's influence adds more hipness, funk, and energy to Chicago's more ballady style.  I really disliked the Peter Cetera fill in (bass player) on the Chicago solo disc as he used vibrato that was irritating, but he doesn't do it here and sounds much better.  The Maurice White fill-in has also changed for EWF and I think the new guy does a better job too than on the Live By Request disc.  Overall, a real fun show to watch and all the horns will sound great on a good sound system.Didn't see a track list - so here it is.Side #1 -- Disc 11. reviewText: I had a real good time with this blu-ray that features a great PQ (AVC coding) and amazing AQ (DTS-HD MA 5.1/2.0). I almost felt like "being there". The combined showcase from Chicago & EWF is very entertaining and enjoyable. You can't just sit down and watch; you will find yourself stand up and shake your body (like all the audience in the Greek Theatre)! I have been a big fan of EWF's and the band is simply amazing in the concert even without Maurice White. Philip Bailey is such a great musician with his great voice and covers M. White's spot very well. He also can play the kalimba as Mr. White does! V. White, who is co-leader and plays the bass, makes us smile and happy with his passionate gestures. As for Chicago, I have to admit I wished Peter Cetera had been there. They are still good but, to me, not enough without the former lead singer. Before I watched the concert, I had no idea what had made these two bands do a concert together. Now I know they have some connections: both of them are brass bands and EWF's "After the love has gone", which the both bands sing and play together, was co-written by Chicago's Bill Champlin.Here's my conclusion: get this blu-ray and have a great time especially when you want "cheer-up" and dance!
Title: N/A
